title: 105_hr1511
content: The "Cost of Higher Education Review Act of 1997" was established to address the significant increase in tuition at public colleges and universities, which outpaced the rise in household income and consumer goods costs. Concerns about college affordability were at an all-time high, making college education one of the most expensive investments for American families. The "National Commission on the Cost of Higher Education" is established by the "Cost of Higher Education Review Act of 1997" to address the rising tuition costs at public colleges and universities. The Commission established by the "Cost of Higher Education Review Act of 1997" consists of 7 members appointed by various leaders and the Secretary of Education. Each member must have expertise in higher education finance, Federal financial aid programs, education economics research, higher education administration, or business efficiency and cost reduction programs. The Commission established by the "Cost of Higher Education Review Act of 1997" consists of 7 members with expertise in higher education finance, Federal financial aid programs, education economics research, higher education administration, or business efficiency and cost reduction programs. The members will elect a Chairman and Vice Chairperson, with a majority needed for a quorum. Appointments must be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Appointments for officers authorized to make appointments must be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment. If an appointment is not made within this timeframe, the Chairman or Ranking Minority Member of specific committees may act on behalf of the Speaker of the House, Majority Leader of the Senate, Minority Leader of the House, or Minority Leader of the Senate. Members of the Commission are entitled to one vote each, vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers and are filled as per original appointment procedures, and members receive no additional pay except for travel expenses as authorized by law. Members of the Commission do not receive extra pay, allowances, or benefits, except for authorized travel expenses. The initial meeting of the Commission must take place within 40 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission's functions are outlined in Section 4. The Commission shall study and make findings and recommendations on the increase in tuition, methods to reduce tuition, trends in administrative costs and faculty workload, and the impact on tuition. The Commission will study trends in faculty workload, faculty-to-student ratios, classroom hours, tenure practices, construction of academic facilities, modernization for new technologies, and the impact on tuition. Additionally, they will examine the impact of institutional financial aid and tuition discounting on tuition increases. The Commission will study the demographics of students receiving financial aid, the impact of aid on attracting students to institutions or fields of study, and the role of Federal financial aid in offsetting cost increases. They will also examine the contribution of laws and regulations to tuition hikes, recommend ways to reduce mandates, and establish a mechanism for timely data distribution on tuition trends. Additionally, they will assess the impact of student financial aid programs on tuition and address other relevant topics. The Commission will submit a final report to the President and Congress within 120 days of its first meeting, detailing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for administrative and legislative action. Recommendations require a majority vote from the Commission before being presented to the President and Congress. The Commission must adopt recommendations by a majority vote before submitting them to the President and Congress. The Commission has the power to adopt recommendations by a majority vote before submitting them to the President and Congress. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, adopt rules and regulations, and request information from federal agencies for the purpose of carrying out the Act. Federal agencies must provide information to the Commission upon request by the Chairperson, subject to legal limitations. The head of agencies can also make facilities, services, and personnel available to the Commission as needed. The Commission can utilize the United States mails and enter into contracts for research purposes. Additionally, agencies can provide personnel to assist the Commission as needed. The Commission can appoint an Executive Director and additional staff to assist in conducting research or surveys for fulfilling its duties. The Chairperson has the power to determine their compensation without following certain regulations. The Commission can appoint an Executive Director and additional staff to assist in conducting research or surveys, with compensation rates not exceeding the maximum rate for level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Commission can appoint an Executive Director and staff with compensation rates not exceeding the maximum rate for level IV of the Executive Schedule. Expenses of the Commission are authorized to be appropriated not to exceed $650,000 and remain available until expended or one year after termination of the Commission. The Commission will cease to exist 60 days after submitting its final report.
